2 Cartesian links and colinks 2.1 The category of cartesian links 2.2 The category of cartesian colinks 2.3 Basic constructions for cartesian links and colinks 2.4 Products and coproducts of cartesian links and colinks 2.5 The tensor product of cartesian colinks 2.6 Fibrational structure of cartesian links and colinks 2.7 The double category of colinks and links 2.8 Notes

2 Cartesian links and colinks 2.1 The category of cartesian links Definition 2.1 Let {\mathcal{C}} be a category with finite products, and let X, X', Y, Y' be objects of {\mathcal{C}}. A cartesian link \binom{f'}{f} : \binom{X'}{X} \to \binom{Y'}{Y} in {\mathcal{C}} is a pair of morphisms f : X \to Y and f : X \times X' \to Y'. Example 2.1 Let f : \mathbb R^m \to \mathbb R^n be a smooth function between Euclidean spaces. There is a cartesian link D (f) : \binom{\mathbb R^m}{\mathbb R^m} \to \binom{\mathbb R^n}{\mathbb R^n} in the category \mathbf{Euc} of Euclidean spaces and smooth functions, called the forward derivative link of f, given by The [what] is f : \mathbb R^m \to \mathbb R^n The [what] is f' : \mathbb R^m \times \mathbb R^m \to \mathbb R^n given by f' (x, v) = v \cdot J_f (x), where J_f (x) is the Jacaobian of f evaluated at x, and \cdot is multiplication of that matrix by the vector v. Proposition 2.1 Let {\mathcal{C}} be a cartesian closed category. Then a colink \binom{X'}{X} \to \binom{Y'}{Y} can be equivalently seen as a morphism X \to Y \times [X', Y'] in {\mathcal{C}}. Proof. Writing \overrightarrow{\mathscr L}({\mathcal{C}}) \left( \binom{X'}{X}, \binom{Y'}{Y} \right) for the set of links \binom{X'}{X} \to \binom{Y'}{Y}, there are natural isomorphisms \overrightarrow{\mathscr L}({\mathcal{C}}) \left( \binom{X'}{X}, \binom{Y'}{Y} \right) = {\mathcal{C}} (X, Y) \times {\mathcal{C}} (X \times X', Y') \cong {\mathcal{C}} (X, Y) \times {\mathcal{C}} (X, [X', Y']) \cong {\mathcal{C}} (X, Y \times [X', Y']) Definition 2.2 Let {\mathcal{C}} be a category with finite products, and let \binom{f'}{f} : \binom{X'}{X} \to \binom{Y'}{Y} and \binom{g'}{g} : \binom{Y'}{Y} \to \binom{Z'}{Z} be cartesian links in {\mathcal{C}}. The composition of links is given by \binom{f'}{f} \binom{g'}{g} : \binom{X'}{X} \to \binom{Z'}{Z} where The [what] is f g : X \to Z The [what] is (f g)' : X \times X' \to Z' given by this diagram Proposition 2.2 Let {\mathcal{C}} be a category with finite products, and let f : \binom{X'}{X} \to \binom{Y'}{Y}, g : \binom{Y'}{Y} \to \binom{Z'}{Z} and h : \binom{Z'}{Z} \to \binom{W'}{W} be cartesian links in {\mathcal{C}}. Then (\binom{f'}{f} \binom{g'}{g}) \binom{h'}{h} = \binom{f'}{f} (\binom{g'}{g} \binom{h'}{h}). Definition 2.3 Let {\mathcal{C}} be a category with finite products, and let X, X' be objects of {\mathcal{C}}. The identity cartesian link 1_{\binom{X'}{X}} : \binom{X'}{X} \to \binom{X'}{X} is given by The [what] is the identity morphism 1_X : X \to X The [what] is the projection \pi_2 : X \times X' \to X' Proposition 2.3 Let {\mathcal{C}} be a category with finite products, and let f : \binom{X'}{X} \to \binom{Y'}{Y} be a cartesian link in {\mathcal{C}}. Then 1_{\binom{X'}{X}} f = f = f 1_{\binom{Y'}{Y}}. Proof. In both cases, the first passes [fix name] are equal by uniltality in {\mathcal{C}}. For the second passes: Left unitality: the composite is depicted by this diagram, which is equal to f' since copy-delete is a comonoid. Right unitality: the composition is depicted by this diagram, which is equal to g' since f is causal and copy-delete is a comonoid. Definition 2.4 Let {\mathcal{C}} be a category with finite products. Then \overrightarrow{\mathscr L}({\mathcal{C}}) is the category whose objects are pairs of objects of {\mathcal{C}}, and whose morphisms are cartesian links in {\mathcal{C}}. 2.2 The category of cartesian colinks Definition 2.5 Let {\mathcal{C}} be a category with finite products, and let X, X', Y, Y' be objects of {\mathcal{C}}. A cartesian colink \binom{f'}{f} : \binom{X'}{X} \to \binom{Y'}{Y} in {\mathcal{C}} is a pair of morphisms f : X \to Y and f' : X \times Y' \to X'. f is called the forwards pass and f' is called the backwards pass. We depict a generic colink \binom{f'}{f} as in this diagram. Example 2.2 Let {\mathcal{C}} be a category with finite products, and let X, Y be objects of {\mathcal{C}}. There is a cartesian colink \pi_1 : \binom{X \times Y}{X \times Y} \to \binom{X}{X}, also known as a lens X \to Y, given by: The forwards pass is the projection \pi_1 : X \times Y \to X The backwards pass is \pi_1' : (X \times Y) \times X \to X \times Y given by \pi_1' ((x, y), x') = (x', y) [TODO - write with string diagram] Similarly there is a cartesian colink \pi_2 : \binom{X \times Y}{X \times Y} \to \binom{Y}{Y}. Example 2.3 Let f : \mathbb R^m \to \mathbb R^n be a smooth function between Euclidean spaces. There is a cartesian colink D (f) : \binom{\mathbb R^m}{\mathbb R^m} \to \binom{\mathbb R^n}{\mathbb R^n} in the category \mathbf{Euc} of Euclidean spaces and smooth functions, called the reverse derivative colink of f, given by The forwards pass is f : \mathbb R^m \to \mathbb R^n The backrwards pass is f' : \mathbb R^m \times \mathbb R^n \to \mathbb R^n given by f' (x, v) = J_f (x)^\top \cdot v, where J_f (x)^\top is the transpose Jacobian of f evaluated at x, and \cdot is multiplication of that matrix by the vector v. Proposition 2.4 Let {\mathcal{C}} be a cartesian closed category. Then a colink \binom{X'}{X} \to \binom{Y'}{Y} in {\mathcal{C}} can be equivalently seen as a morphism X \to Y \times [Y', X'] in {\mathcal{C}}. Proof. Writing \overleftarrow{\mathscr L}({\mathcal{C}}) \left( \binom{X'}{X}, \binom{Y'}{Y} \right) for the set of colinks \binom{X'}{X} \to \binom{Y'}{Y}, there are natural isomorphisms \overleftarrow{\mathscr L}({\mathcal{C}}) \left( \binom{X'}{X}, \binom{Y'}{Y} \right) = {\mathcal{C}} (X, Y) \times {\mathcal{C}} (X \times Y', X') \cong {\mathcal{C}} (X, Y) \times {\mathcal{C}} (X, [Y', X']) \cong {\mathcal{C}} (X, Y \times [Y', X']) Definition 2.6 Let {\mathcal{C}} be a category with finite products, and let \binom{f'}{f} : \binom{X'}{X} \to \binom{Y'}{Y} and \binom{g'}{g} : \binom{Y'}{Y} \to \binom{Z'}{Z} be cartesian colinks in {\mathcal{C}}. The composition of the colinks is given by \binom{f'}{f} \binom{g'}{g} : \binom{X'}{X} \to \binom{Z'}{Z} where The forwards pass is f g : X \to Z The backwards pass is (f g)' : X \times Z' \to X' defined in the internal language of {\mathcal{C}} by (f g)' (x, z) = f' (x, g' (f (x), z)) [TODO - write this definition in string diagrams instead] Proposition 2.5 Let {\mathcal{C}} be a category with finite products, and let \binom{f'}{f} : \binom{X'}{X} \to \binom{Y'}{Y}, \binom{g'}{g} : \binom{Y'}{Y} \to \binom{Z'}{Z} and \binom{h'}{h} : \binom{Z'}{Z} \to \binom{W'}{W} be cartesian colinks in {\mathcal{C}}. Then (\binom{f'}{f} \binom{g'}{g}) \binom{h'}{h} = \binom{f'}{f} (\binom{g'}{g} \binom{h'}{h}). Definition 2.7 Let {\mathcal{C}} be a category with finite products, and let X, X' be objects of {\mathcal{C}}. The identity cartesian colink 1_{\binom{X'}{X}} : \binom{X'}{X} \to \binom{X'}{X} is given by The forwards pass is the identity morphism 1_X : X \to X The backwwards pass is the projection \pi_2 : X \times X' \to X' Proposition 2.6 Let {\mathcal{C}} be a category with finite products, and let f : \binom{X'}{X} \to \binom{Y'}{Y} be a cartesian colink in {\mathcal{C}}. Then 1_{\binom{X'}{X}} f = f = f 1_{\binom{Y'}{Y}}. Definition 2.8 Let {\mathcal{C}} be a category with finite products. Then \overleftarrow{\mathscr L}({\mathcal{C}}) is the category whose objects are pairs of objects of {\mathcal{C}}, and whose morphisms are cartesian colinks in {\mathcal{C}}. Proposition 2.7 There is a functor D : \mathbf{Euc} \to \overleftarrow{\mathscr L}(\mathbf{Euc}) given on objects by D (X) = \binom{X}{X} and on morphisms by D (f) from example 2.3. 2.3 Basic constructions for cartesian links and colinks Proposition 2.8 let {\mathcal{C}} be a category with finite products. Then there is a functor \binom{-}{-} : {\mathcal{C}} \times {\mathcal{C}} \to \overrightarrow{\mathscr L}({\mathcal{C}}) given by: On objects: (X, X') \mapsto \binom{X'}{X} On morphisms: (f, g) \mapsto \binom{\pi_2 g}{f} [todo - fix this ambiguous notation] Proposition 2.9 Let {\mathcal{C}} be a category with finite products. Then there is a functor \binom{-}{-} : {\mathcal{C}} \times {\mathcal{C}}^\mathrm{op}\to \overleftarrow{\mathscr L}({\mathcal{C}}) given by: On objects: (X, X') \mapsto \binom{X'}{X} On morphisms: (f, g) \mapsto \binom{\pi_2 g}{f} Proposition 2.10 Let {\mathcal{C}} be a category with finite products. Then there is a functor \mathbb E : \overrightarrow{\mathscr L}({\mathcal{C}}) \to {\mathcal{C}} [todo name this thing], given by: On objects, \mathbb E \binom{X'}{X} = X On morphisms \mathbb E \binom{f'}{f} = f. Proposition 2.11 Let {\mathcal{C}} be a category with finite products. Then there is a functor \mathbb F: \overleftarrow{\mathscr L}({\mathcal{C}}) \to {\mathcal{C}}, called the forwards pass functor, given by: On objects, \mathbb F\binom{X'}{X} = X On morphisms, \mathbb F\binom{f'}{f} = f Proposition 2.12 Let {\mathcal{C}} be a category with finite products. Then there is a functor \mathbb L : \overrightarrow{\mathscr L}({\mathcal{C}}) \to {\mathcal{C}}, called the link functor, given by: On objects, \mathbb L \binom{X'}{X} = X \times X' On links \binom{f'}{f} : \binom{X'}{X} \to \binom{Y'}{Y}, the morphism \mathbb L \binom{f'}{f} : X \times X' \to Y \times Y' is given by this diagram Proposition 2.13 Let {\mathcal{C}} be a category with finite products. Then there is a functor \mathbb K: \overleftarrow{\mathscr L}({\mathcal{C}})^\mathrm{op}\to \mathbf{Set}, called the continuation functor, given by: On objects, \mathbb K\binom{X'}{X} = {\mathcal{C}} (X, X') On morphisms \binom{f'}{f} : \binom{X'}{X} \to \binom{Y'}{Y}, \mathbb K\binom{f'}{f} : {\mathcal{C}} (Y, Y') \to {\mathcal{C}} (X, X') is given by \mathbb K\binom{f'}{f} (k) given by this diagram Proposition 2.14 Let {\mathcal{C}} be a category with finite products. Then the functor \mathbb K: \overleftarrow{\mathscr L}({\mathcal{C}})^\mathrm{op}\to \mathbf{Set} is representable, with representing object \binom{1}{1}. Proposition 2.15 Let {\mathcal{C}} be a cartesian closed category. Then there is a functor \mathbb K: \overleftarrow{\mathscr L}({\mathcal{C}})^\mathrm{op}\to {\mathcal{C}}, called the closed continuation functor, given by: On objects, \mathbb K\binom{X'}{X} = [X, X'] On morphisms [TODO] [TODO - talk about the ambiguous notation for \mathbb K, it could be made precise using enrichment but I don’t consider it worth it] Proposition 2.16 Let {\mathcal{C}} be a category with finite products. Let \left< \mathbb E, \mathbb L \right> : \overrightarrow{\mathscr L}({\mathcal{C}}) \to {\mathcal{C}} \times {\mathcal{C}} be the functor given by \binom{X'}{X} \mapsto (X, X \times X'). Then there is an adjunction \left< \mathbb E, \mathbb L \right> \dashv \binom{-}{-}. Proof. There are natural isomorphisms ({\mathcal{C}} \times {\mathcal{C}}) ((X, X \times X'), (Y, Y')) = {\mathcal{C}} (X, Y) \times {\mathcal{C}} (X \times X', Y') = \overrightarrow{\mathscr L}({\mathcal{C}}) \left( \binom{X'}{X}, \binom{Y'}{Y} \right) Proposition 2.17 Let {\mathcal{C}} be a cartesian closed category. Let \left< \mathbb F, \mathbb K\right> : \overleftarrow{\mathscr L}({\mathcal{C}}) \to {\mathcal{C}} \times {\mathcal{C}}^\mathrm{op} be the functor given by \binom{X'}{X} \mapsto (X, [X, X']). Then there is an adjunction \left< \mathbb F, \mathbb K\right> \dashv \binom{-}{-}. Proof. There are natural isomorphisms ({\mathcal{C}} \times {\mathcal{C}})^\mathrm{op}((X, [X, X']), (Y, Y')) = {\mathcal{C}} (X, Y) \times {\mathcal{C}} (Y', [X, X']) \cong {\mathcal{C}} (X, Y) \times {\mathcal{C}} (X \times Y', X') = \overleftarrow{\mathscr L}({\mathcal{C}}) \left( \binom{X'}{X}, \binom{Y'}{Y} \right) 2.4 Products and coproducts of cartesian links and colinks Proposition 2.18 Let {\mathcal{C}} be a category with finite (all) products. Then \overrightarrow{\mathscr L}({\mathcal{C}}) has finite (all) products given on objects by \binom{X'}{X} \times \binom{Y'}{Y} = \binom{Y \times Y'}{X \times X'}, respectively \prod_{i : I} \binom{X'_i}{X_i} = \binom{\prod_{i : I} X'_i}{\prod_{i : I} X_i}. Proposition 2.19 Let {\mathcal{C}} with a category with finite products whose terminal object is 1. Then \binom{1}{1} is terminal in \overrightarrow{\mathscr L}({\mathcal{C}}). Proposition 2.20 Let {\mathcal{C}} be a category with finite (all) products and finite (all) distributive coproducts. Then \overleftarrow{\mathscr L}({\mathcal{C}}) has finite (all) products given on objects by \binom{X'}{X} \times \binom{Y'}{Y} = \binom{X' + Y'}{X \times Y}, respectively \prod_{i : I} \binom{X'_i}{X_i} = \binom{\sum_{i : I} X'_i}{\prod_{i : I} X_i}. Proposition 2.21 Let {\mathcal{C}} be a category with finite products, with an initial object 0 and a terminal object 1. Then \binom{0}{1} is terminal in \overleftarrow{\mathscr L}({\mathcal{C}}). Proposition 2.22 Let {\mathcal{C}} be a cartesian closed category and Z an object of {\mathcal{C}}. Let R_Z : \overrightarrow{\mathscr L}({\mathcal{C}}) \to {\mathcal{C}} be the functor defined on objects by R_Z \binom{X'}{X} = X \times [Z, X']. [todo - is there a better way to define it?] Then \binom{Z}{-} \dashv R_Z. Proof. There are natural isomorphisms \overrightarrow{\mathscr L}({\mathcal{C}}) \left( \binom{Z}{X}, \binom{Y'}{Y} \right) \cong {\mathcal{C}} (X, Y \times [Z, Y']) = {\mathcal{C}} (X, R_Z \binom{Y'}{Y}) Proposition 2.23 Let {\mathcal{C}} be a cartesian closed category and Z an object of {\mathcal{C}}. Let R_Z : \overleftarrow{\mathscr L}({\mathcal{C}}) \to {\mathcal{C}} be the functor defined on objects by R_Z \binom{X'}{X} = X \times [X', Z]. Then \binom{Z}{-} \dashv R_Z. Proof. There are natural isomorphisms \overleftarrow{\mathscr L}({\mathcal{C}}) \left( \binom{Z}{X}, \binom{Y'}{Y} \right) \cong {\mathcal{C}} (X, Y \times [Y', Z]) = {\mathcal{C}} (X, R_Z \binom{Y'}{Y}) Proposition 2.24 Let {\mathcal{C}} be a category with finite products and finite (all) coproducts. Then \overrightarrow{\mathscr L}({\mathcal{C}}) has finite (all) coproducts that have the form \binom{Z}{X} + \binom{Z}{Y} = \binom{Z}{X + Y}, respectively \sum_{i : I} \binom{Z}{X_i} = \binom{Z}{\sum_{i : I} X_i}. Proposition 2.25 Let {\mathcal{C}} be a category with finite products and finite (all) distributive coproducts. Then \overleftarrow{\mathscr L}({\mathcal{C}}) has finite (all) coproducts that have the form \binom{Z}{X} + \binom{Z}{Y} = \binom{Z}{X + Y}, respectively \sum_{i : I} \binom{Z}{X_i} = \binom{Z}{\sum_{i : I} X_i}. In the case that {\mathcal{C}} is cartesian closed and has coproducts (which are automatically distributive) we get a different proof using the fact that \binom{Z}{-} : {\mathcal{C}} \to \overleftarrow{\mathscr L}({\mathcal{C}}) preserves colimits. Proposition 2.26 Let {\mathcal{C}} be a category with finite products and an initial object 0. Then for any object X of {\mathcal{C}}, \binom{X}{0} is initial in \overleftarrow{\mathscr L}({\mathcal{C}}). Proposition 2.27 Let {\mathcal{C}} be a category with finite products and finite (all) distributive coproducts. Then the coproduct of \overleftarrow{\mathscr L}({\mathcal{C}}) distributes over the product: (\binom{Z}{A} + \binom{Z}{B}) \times \binom{C'}{C} \cong (\binom{Z}{A} \times \binom{C'}{C}) + (\binom{Z}{B} \times \binom{C'}{C}) Example 2.4 The category \overleftarrow{\mathscr L}(\mathbf{Set}) does not have all coproducts, but it does have some coproducts that are not of the form of proposition 2.25. [todo example of a missing coproduct] An example of a coproduct present in \overleftarrow{\mathscr L}(\mathbf{Set}) not of the form of proposition 2.25 is \binom{0}{1} + \binom{1}{1} = \binom{0}{2} 2.5 The tensor product of cartesian colinks Definition 2.9 Let {\mathcal{C}} be a category with finite products, and let \binom{f'}{f} : \binom{X'}{X} \to \binom{Y'}{Y} and \binom{g'}{g} : \binom{Y'}{Y} \to \binom{W'}{W} be cartesian colinks in {\mathcal{C}}. Their tensor product is the colink \binom{f'}{f} \otimes \binom{g'}{g} : \binom{X' \times Z'}{X \times Z} \to \binom{Y' \times W'}{Y \times W} given as follows: The forwards pass is given by f \times g : X \times Z \to Y \times W The backwards pass is given by (f \times g)' : (X \times Z) \times (Y' \times W') \to X' \times Z', (f \times g)' ((x, z), (y', w')) = (f' (x, y'), g' (z, w')) [todo write with string diagrams] Proposition 2.28 Let {\mathcal{C}} be a category with finite products. The tensor product of colinks makes \overleftarrow{\mathscr L}({\mathcal{C}}) into a symmetric monoidal category, given on objects by pairwise cartesian product. The monoidal unit is I = \binom{1}{1}. Definition 2.10 Let {\mathcal{C}} be a category with finite products. We write the functor \binom{1}{-} : {\mathcal{C}} \to \overleftarrow{\mathscr L}({\mathcal{C}}) without notation. Objects and colinks in the image of this functor are called purely covariant We write -^* for the functor \binom{-}{1} : {\mathcal{C}}^\mathrm{op}\to \overleftarrow{\mathscr L}({\mathcal{C}}). Objects and colinks in the image of this functor are called purely contravariant Proposition 2.29 Let {\mathcal{C}} be a category with finite products. Every object of \overleftarrow{\mathscr L}({\mathcal{C}}) can be written as the tensor product of a purely covariant and a purely contravariant object, namely \binom{X'}{X} \cong X \otimes X'^* Definition 2.11 Let {\mathcal{C}} be a category with finite products. For every object X of {\mathcal{C}}, there is a colink \varepsilon_X : \binom{X}{X} \to I, called a counit, given by: The forwards pass is the unique morphism X \to 1 The backwards pass is the identity morphism X \times 1 \to X Proposition 2.30 Let {\mathcal{C}} be a category with finite products, and let f : X \to Y be a morphism of {\mathcal{C}}. Then the follow diagram in \overleftarrow{\mathscr L}({\mathcal{C}}) commutes: [todo diagram] [todo state as dinaturality] Proposition 2.31 Let {\mathcal{C}} be a category with finite products, and let \binom{f'}{f} : \binom{X'}{X} \to \binom{Y'}{Y} be a cartesian colink in {\mathcal{C}}. Then \binom{f'}{f} can be decomposed as follows: [todo] [todo string diagram] [todo - interaction of tensor product with products and coproducts] 2.6 Fibrational structure of cartesian links and colinks Proposition 2.32 Let {\mathcal{C}} be a category with finite products, and X an object of {\mathcal{C}}. Then the functor X \times - : {\mathcal{C}} \to {\mathcal{C}} is a comonad on {\mathcal{C}}. Definition 2.12 Let {\mathcal{C}} be a category with finite products, and X an object of {\mathcal{C}}. We write {\mathcal{C}} [X] for the cokleisli category of the X \times - comonad. Proposition 2.33 Let {\mathcal{C}} be a category with finite products, and X an object of {\mathcal{C}}. Then {\mathcal{C}} [X] has finite products. Proposition 2.34 Let {\mathcal{C}} be a category with finite products, and f : X \to Y a morphism of {\mathcal{C}}. Then f induces a functor f^* : {\mathcal{C}} [Y] \to {\mathcal{C}} [X]. Proposition 2.35 Let {\mathcal{C}} be a category with finite products. Then the functor \mathbb E : \overrightarrow{\mathscr L}({\mathcal{C}}) \to {\mathcal{C}} is a fibration. For each object X of {\mathcal{C}}, the fibre \mathbb E^{-1} (X) is isomorphic to {\mathcal{C}} [X], and for each morphism f : X \to Y of {\mathcal{C}}, the reindexing functor \mathbb E^{-1} (f) : {\mathcal{C}} [Y] \to {\mathcal{C}} [X] is given by f^*. Proposition 2.36 Let {\mathcal{C}} be a category with finite products. Then the forwards pass functor \mathbb F: \overleftarrow{\mathscr L}({\mathcal{C}}) \to {\mathcal{C}} is a fibration. For each object X of {\mathcal{C}}, the fibre \mathbb F^{-1} (X) of \overleftarrow{\mathscr L}({\mathcal{C}}) over X is isomorphic to {\mathcal{C}} [X]^\mathrm{op}, and for each morphism f : X \to Y of {\mathcal{C}}, the reindexing functor \mathbb F^{-1} (f) : {\mathcal{C}} [Y]^\mathrm{op}\to {\mathcal{C}} [X]^\mathrm{op} is given by f^*. 2.7 The double category of colinks and links Definition 2.13 Let F : {\mathcal{C}}^\mathrm{op}\to \mathbf{Cat} be an indexed category. Let \binom{v_1'}{v_1} : \binom{X'}{X} \to \binom{Z'}{Z} and \binom{v_2'}{v_2} : \binom{Y'}{Y} \to \binom{W'}{W} be morphisms of \int_{X : {\mathcal{C}}} F (X), and let \binom{h_1'}{h_1} : \binom{X'}{X} \to \binom{Y'}{Y} and \binom{h_2'}{h_2} : \binom{Z'}{Z} \to \binom{W'}{W} be morhisms of \int_{X : {\mathcal{C}}} F (X)^\mathrm{op}. Unpacking, this means v_1 : X \to Z in {\mathcal{C}} and v_1' : X' \to F (v_1) (Z') in F (X) v_2 : Y \to W in {\mathcal{C}} and v_2' : Y' \to F (v_2) (W') in F (Y) h_1 : X \to Y in {\mathcal{C}} and h_1' : F (h_1) (Y') \to X' in F (X) h_2 : Z \to W in {\mathcal{C}} and h_2' : F (h_2) (W') \to Z' in F(Z) We say that the square diagram formally commutes if Condition 1 Condition 2 Definition 2.14 Let {\mathcal{C}} be a category with finite products. We say that a square of the form diagram formally commutes, where \binom{h_1'}{h_1} and \binom{h_2'}{h_2} are colinks in {\mathcal{C}} and \binom{v_1'}{v_1} and \binom{v_2'}{v_2} are links in {\mathcal{C}}, if: Condition 1 Condition 2, which can alternatively be written as an equation between string diagrams: Definition 2.15 Let {\mathcal{C}} be a category with finite products. Then {\mathcal{L}} ({\mathcal{C}}) is the double category where: Objects are pairs of objects of {\mathcal{C}} Loose 1-cells are cartesian colinks in {\mathcal{C}} Tight 1-cells are cartesian links in {\mathcal{C}} There is a unique 2-cell [write] when the square formally commutes. 2.8 Notes Links first appeared to my knowledge as morphisms in the total category of Bart Jacobs’ simple fibration [Jacobs, Categorical logic and type theory] Their central role in categorical systems theory was recognised by David Jaz Myers [Myers, Categorical systems theory], where they were called charts, as well as defining the double category of links and colinks Colinks have a much more complicated history [todo] The notation {\mathcal{C}} [X] for the cokleisli category of X \times - is from [Lambek and Scott, Introduction to higher order categorical logic] Wiring diagrams operad?

3 Actegories and enriched categories 3.1 Actegories 3.2 Encriched categories 3.3 Enriched links and colinks 3.4 Parametrisation for actegories 3.5 Parametrisation for enriched categories 3.6 Locally graded categories 3.7 Parametrised colinks

3 Actegories and enriched categories 3.1 Actegories 3.2 Encriched categories 3.3 Enriched links and colinks Definition 3.1 Let {\mathcal{M}} be a monoidal category. Let {\mathcal{D}} be a category enriched in {\mathcal{M}}, and let {\mathcal{C}} be a category equipped with a left action of {\mathcal{M}}. Let X, Y be objects of {\mathcal{C}} and X', Y' objects of {\mathcal{D}}. An enriched link f : \binom{X'}{X} \to \binom{Y'}{Y} is a morphism f : X \to [X', Y'] \bullet Y in {\mathcal{C}}. Definition 3.2 Let f : \binom{X'}{X} \to \binom{Y'}{Y} and g : \binom{Y'}{Y} \to \binom{Z'}{Z} be enriched links. The composition fg is the enriched link \binom{X'}{X} \to \binom{Z'}{Z} given by X \xrightarrow{f} [X', Y'] \bullet Y \xrightarrow{[X', Y'] \bullet g} [X', Y'] \bullet [Y', X'] \bullet Z \xrightarrow{\cong} [X', Y'] \otimes [Y', Z'] \bullet Z \xrightarrow{\circ \bullet Z} [X', Z'] \bullet Z Proposition 3.1 Let f : \binom{X'}{X} \to \binom{Y'}{Y}, g : \binom{Y'}{Y} \to \binom{Z'}{Z} and \binom{h'}{h} : \binom{Z'}{Z} \to \binom{W'}{W} be enriched links. Then (fg)h = f(gh). Definition 3.3 Let {\mathcal{M}} be a monoidal category. Let {\mathcal{D}} be a category enriched in {\mathcal{M}}, and let {\mathcal{C}} be a category equipped with a left action of {\mathcal{M}}. Let X be an object of {\mathcal{C}} and X' an object of {\mathcal{D}}. The identity enriched link \binom{X'}{X} \to \binom{X'}{X} is the morphism X \to [X', X'] \bullet X given by X \xrightarrow\cong I \bullet X \xrightarrow{1_{X'} \bullet X} [X', X'] \bullet X Proposition 3.2 Let f : \binom{X'}{X} \to \binom{Y'}{Y} be an enriched link. Then 1_{\binom{X'}{X}} f = f = f 1_{\binom{Y'}{Y}}. Proof. Left unit: diagram Right unit: [todo] Definition 3.4 Let {\mathcal{M}} be a monoidal category. Let {\mathcal{D}} be a category enriched in {\mathcal{M}}, and let {\mathcal{C}} be a category equipped with a right action of {\mathcal{M}}. Let X, Y be objects of {\mathcal{C}} and X', Y' objects of {\mathcal{D}}. An enriched colink f : \binom{X'}{X} \to \binom{Y'}{Y} is a morphism f : X \to Y \bullet [Y', X'] in {\mathcal{C}}. Definition 3.5 Let f : \binom{X'}{X} \to \binom{Y'}{Y} and g : \binom{Y'}{Y} \to \binom{Z'}{Z} be enriched colinks. The composition fg is the enriched colink \binom{X'}{X} \to \binom{Z'}{Z} given by X \xrightarrow{f} Y \bullet [Y', X'] \xrightarrow{g \bullet [Y', X']} Z \bullet [Z', Y'] \bullet [Y', X'] \xrightarrow{\cong} Z \bullet [Z', Y'] \otimes [Y', X'] \xrightarrow{Z \bullet \circ} Z \bullet [Z', Y'] 3.4 Parametrisation for actegories Definition 3.6 Let {\mathcal{C}} be a category and {\mathcal{M}} a monoidal category with a right action on {\mathcal{C}}. Let X and Y be objects of {\mathcal{C}}. A parametrised morphism f : X \to Y in {\mathcal{C}} consists of an object M of {\mathcal{M}} and a morphism f : X \bullet M \to Y. We call M the parameter object of f. Definition 3.7 Let {\mathcal{C}} be a category and {\mathcal{M}} a monoidal category with a right action on {\mathcal{C}}.Let f : X \to Y and g : Y \to Z be parametrised morphisms with parameter objects M, N. The composition fg : X \to Z is the parametrised morphism with parameter object M \otimes N given by X \bullet M \otimes N \xrightarrow{\cong} X \bullet M \bullet N \xrightarrow{f \bullet N} Y \bullet N \xrightarrow{g} Z Definition 3.8 Let {\mathcal{C}} be a category and {\mathcal{M}} a monoidal category with a right action on {\mathcal{C}}. Let X be an object of {\mathcal{C}}. The identity parametrised morphism 1_X : X \to X is given by the monoidal unit I of {\mathcal{C}} and the identity morphism X \bullet I \to X. Definition 3.9 Let X and Y be objects of {\mathcal{C}}. Then there is a category \overleftarrow{\mathscr P}({\mathcal{C}})_g (X, Y) where - Objects are pairs of an object M of {\mathcal{M}} and a morphism f : X \bullet M \to Y of {\mathcal{C}} - Morphisms (M, f) \to (N, g) are morphisms M \to N such that [diagram] Proposition 3.3 \overleftarrow{\mathscr P}({\mathcal{C}})_g (-, -) defines a functor {\mathcal{C}}^\mathrm{op}\times {\mathcal{C}} \to \mathbf{Cat}. Definition 3.10 We define \overleftarrow{\mathscr P}({\mathcal{C}})_v as the total category \iint \overleftarrow{\mathscr P}({\mathcal{C}})_g regarded as a two-sided fibration. Concretely: - Objects of \overleftarrow{\mathscr P}({\mathcal{C}})_v are parametrised morphisms X \bullet M \to Y - Morphisms from f : X \bullet M \to Y to g : X' \bullet N \to Y' are triples of morphisms X \to X' and Y \to Y' of {\mathcal{C}} and M \to N of {\mathcal{M}} such that [diagram] Proposition 3.4 Let {\mathcal{C}} be a category and {\mathcal{M}} a monoidal category with a right action on {\mathcal{C}}. There are functors S, T : \overleftarrow{\mathscr P}({\mathcal{C}})_v \to {\mathcal{C}} respectively taking a parametrised morphism to its source and its target object. Proposition 3.5 Let {\mathcal{C}} be a category and {\mathcal{M}} a monoidal category with a right action on {\mathcal{C}}. Let f : X \to Y, g : Y \to Z and h : Z \to W be parametrised morphisms in {\mathcal{C}}. Then (fg)h \cong f(gh) in \overleftarrow{\mathscr P}({\mathcal{C}})_v. Proposition 3.6 Let {\mathcal{C}} be a category and {\mathcal{M}} a monoidal category with a right action on {\mathcal{C}}. Let f : X \to Y be a parametrised morphism in {\mathcal{C}}. Then 1_X f \cong f \cong f 1_Y in \overleftarrow{\mathscr P}({\mathcal{C}})_v. Proposition 3.7 Let {\mathcal{C}} be a category and {\mathcal{M}} a monoidal category with a right action on {\mathcal{C}}. There is a double category \overleftarrow{\mathscr P}({\mathcal{C}}) whose objects are objects of {\mathcal{C}}, loose 1-cells are parametrised morphisms of {\mathcal{C}}, tight 1-cells are ordinary morphisms of {\mathcal{C}}, and 2-cells are morphisms of {\mathcal{M}}. Proposition 3.8 Let {\mathcal{C}} be a category and {\mathcal{M}} a monoidal category with a right action on {\mathcal{C}}. The functor \mathbb P : \overleftarrow{\mathscr P}({\mathcal{C}})_v \to {\mathcal{M}}, taking a parametrised morphism to its parameter object. Proposition 3.9 The functor \mathbb P : \overleftarrow{\mathscr P}({\mathcal{C}})_v \to {\mathcal{M}} is a fibration. 3.5 Parametrisation for enriched categories Definition 3.6 Let {\mathcal{M}} be a monoidal category and {\mathcal{C}} be a category enriched in {\mathcal{M}}. Let X and Y be objects of {\mathcal{C}}. A parametrised morphism f : X \to Y in {\mathcal{C}} consists of an object M of {\mathcal{M}} and a morphism f : {\mathcal{M}} \to [X, Y]. We call M the parameter object of f. Proposition 3.10 Let {\mathcal{M}} be a monoidal category and {\mathcal{C}} be a cateogry enriched in {\mathcal{M}}. Let X and Y be objects of {\mathcal{C}}. Then the slice category {\mathcal{M}} / [X, Y] has as its objects the parametrised morphisms X \to Y, i.e. pairs of an object M of {\mathcal{M}} and a morphism M \to [X, Y]. Proposition 3.11 There is a functor {\mathcal{M}} / [-, -] : {\mathcal{C}}^\mathrm{op}\times {\mathcal{C}} \to \mathbf{Cat} given by the composite {\mathcal{C}}^\mathrm{op}\times {\mathcal{C}} \xrightarrow{[-, -]} {\mathcal{M}} \xrightarrow{{\mathcal{M}} / -} \mathbf{Cat} Sightly more concretely, in the case that {\mathcal{M}} = \mathbf{Set}, a parametrised morphism X \to Y consists of a set M and a function f : M \to {\mathcal{C}} (X, Y). Given morphisms s : X' \to X and t : Y \to Y' of {\mathcal{C}}, the functor {\mathcal{M}} / [s, t] : {\mathcal{M}} / [X, Y] \to {\mathcal{M}} / [X', Y'] takes the object f to the parametrised morphism ({\mathcal{M}} / [s, t]) (f) : M \to [X', Y'] taking m to the composite X' \xrightarrow{s} X \xrightarrow{f (m)} Y \xrightarrow{t} Y' Definition 3.11 Let {\mathcal{M}} be a monoidal category and {\mathcal{C}} a category enriched in {\mathcal{M}}. The category \overleftarrow{\mathscr P}({\mathcal{C}})_v is defined as the total category \iint {\mathcal{M}} / [-, -] regarded as a two-sided fibration. Concretely, objects of \overleftarrow{\mathscr P}({\mathcal{C}})_v are parametrised morphisms f : M \to [X, Y], and a morphism from f to g : N \to [X', Y'] is a triple of morphisms X \to X' and Y \to Y' in {\mathcal{C}} and M \to N in {\mathcal{M}} such that [todo diagram] The fibration \overleftarrow{\mathscr P}({\mathcal{C}})_v \to {\mathcal{C}} taking f : M \to [X, Y] to X is called the domain fibration, and the opfibration \overleftarrow{\mathscr P}({\mathcal{C}})_v \to {\mathcal{C}} taking f : M \to [X, Y] to Y is called the codomain opfibration. 3.6 Locally graded categories Definition 3.12 Let {\mathcal{M}} be a monoidal category. A locally {\mathcal{M}}-graded category is a category {\mathcal{C}} enriched in the category of presheaves [{\mathcal{M}}^\mathrm{op}, \mathbf{Set}] with the monoidal structure given by Day convolution. Definition 3.13 Let {\mathcal{M}} be a monoidal category and {\mathcal{C}} a locally {\mathcal{M}}-graded category. Let X, Y be objects of {\mathcal{C}}. A parametrised morphism f : X \to Y consists of an object M of {\mathcal{M}} and an element f : {\mathcal{C}} (X, Y) (M). We call M the parameter object of f. If {\mathcal{C}} is a locally {\mathcal{M}}-graded category, then composition of morphisms in {\mathcal{C}} defines a morphism of presheaves {\mathcal{M}}^\mathrm{op}\to \mathbf{Set}, \circ : {\mathcal{C}} (X, Y) \otimes {\mathcal{C}} (Y, Z) \to {\mathcal{C}} (X, Z) where \otimes is Day convolution, i.e. for every object M of {\mathcal{M}} a function \circ_M : \int^{M_1, M_2 : {\mathcal{M}}} {\mathcal{M}} (M, M_1 \otimes M_2) \times {\mathcal{C}} (X, Y) (M_1) \times {\mathcal{C}} (Y, Z) (M_2) \to {\mathcal{C}} (X, Z) (M) where the left hand side is the set of equivalence classes of tuples (M_1, M_2, \alpha : M \to M_1 \otimes M_2, f : {\mathcal{C}} (X, Y) (M_1), g : {\mathcal{C}} (Y, Z) (M_2)). Definition 3.14 Let {\mathcal{M}} be a monoidal category and {\mathcal{C}} a locally {\mathcal{M}}-graded category. Let f : X \to Y and g : Y \to Z be parametrised morphisms with parameter objects M, N. Their composition is the parametrised morphism with parameter object M \otimes N and the element of {\mathcal{C}} (X, Z) (M \otimes N) given by \circ_{M \otimes N} (M, N, 1_{M \otimes N}, f, g). If {\mathcal{C}} is a locally {\mathcal{M}}-graded category, then the identity morphisms of {\mathcal{C}} define a morphism of presheaves 1_X : I \to {\mathcal{C}} (X, X) i.e. for every object M of {\mathcal{M}} a function (1_X)_M : {\mathcal{M}} (I, M) \to {\mathcal{C}} (X, X) (M) Definition 3.15 Let {\mathcal{M}} be a monoidal category and {\mathcal{C}} a locally {\mathcal{M}}-graded category. Let X be an object of {\mathcal{C}}. The identity parametried morphism X \to X is given by the parameter object I and the element of {\mathcal{C}} (X, X) (I) given by (1_X)_I (1_I). Definition 3.16 Let {\mathcal{M}} be a monoidal category and {\mathcal{C}} a locally {\mathcal{M}}-graded category. Let X, Y be objects of {\mathcal{C}}. Then we define the category \overleftarrow{\mathscr P}({\mathcal{C}})_g (X, Y) to be the category of elements \int^{M : {\mathcal{M}}} {\mathcal{C}} (X, Y) (M). Written out, objects of \overleftarrow{\mathscr P}({\mathcal{C}})_g (X, Y) are parametrised morphisms X \to Y, and a morphism from (M, f) \to (N, g) is given by a morphism h : M \to N such that f = {\mathcal{C}} (X, Y) (h) (g). Proposition 3.12 \overleftarrow{\mathscr P}({\mathcal{C}})_g (-, -) defines a functor {\mathcal{C}}^\mathrm{op}\times {\mathcal{C}} \to \mathbf{Cat}. 3.7 Parametrised colinks The central construction of categorical cybernetics is categories of parametrised colinks. At this stage the symmetry breaks: we always parametrise colinks, and consider morphisms between them given by non-parametrised links. Let {\mathcal{C}} be a category with finite products, and consider the category \overleftarrow{\mathscr L}({\mathcal{C}}). This category acts on itself by the tensor product of colinks. A parametrised colink \binom{X'}{X} \to \binom{Y'}{Y} consists of a colink \binom{X'}{X} \otimes \binom{P'}{P} \to \binom{Y'}{Y}. Unpacking, this is: A pair of objects P and P' A forwards pass X \times P \to Y A backwards pass X \times P \times Y' \to X' A backwards pass on parameters X \times P \times Y' \to P'
